questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with epigastric pain and melena. Upper endoscopy reveals a well-defined ulcer with a punched-out appearance in the gastric antrum. Histological examination of the ulcer base shows inflammatory cells, granulation tissue, and fibrosis. What is the most likely histological finding from superficial to deep in this ulcer?

options.label: A
options.text: Inflammatory infiltrate---Necrotic debris----- Granulation tissue---Fibrous tissue

options.label: C
options.text: Necrotic debris----- Granulation tissue---Inflammatory infiltrate--- Fibrous tissue

questions.correct_answer: D. Necrotic debris-----Inflammatory infiltrate---Granulation tissue---Fibrous tissue
questions.explanation: Ans. D. Necrotic debris-----Inflammatory infiltrate---Granulation tissue---Fibrous tissue

questions.text: A second-year medical student Ravi Kumar is reading the chapter of gastrointestinal tract from “Review of Pathology” book. To test his thoroughness of concepts, you ask him to consider the following statements regarding inflammatory bowel disease: Ulcerative colitis (UC) involves terminal ileum and rarely causes proctitis Cobblestone appearance of bowel is seen in Crohn's disease Skip lesions are a characteristic of ulcerative colitis but never seen in Crohn's disease Ulcerative colitis is more common in smokers than non-smokers Which of the statements given above is/are correct?
The following have strong causal association with H. pylori infection except:

A 32-year-old male presents with recurrent abdominal pain, diarrhea, and weight loss. Colonoscopy reveals multiple aphthous ulcers, skip lesions, and areas of cobblestone appearance in the terminal ileum and colon. Biopsy of the affected mucosa demonstrates transmural inflammation with non-caseating granulomas. Which of the following histological findings is most characteristic of Crohn's disease in the biopsy of this patient?

An 80-year-old man complains of abdominal pain and bright red blood in his stool. An X-ray film of the abdomen shows fecal impaction in the rectosigmoid region. Which of the following pathologic lesions is most likely to be found in this patient?
Which of the following is a histological feature of Whipple’s disease?

options.label: A
options.text: Infiltration of histiocytes in the lamina propria

options.label: C
options.text: Macrophages with PAS (+) material inside the lamina propria

questions.correct_answer: C. Macrophages with PAS (+) material inside the lamina propria
questions.explanation: Ans. C. Macrophages with PAS (+) material inside the lamina propria

questions.text: What is false about Meckel’s diverticulitis?

options.label: A
options.text: Remnant of proximal part of vitellointestinal duct

questions.correct_answer: C. Present in 3% of the population
questions.explanation: Ans. C. Present in 3% of the population

questions.text: Backwash ileitis is seen in:

A portion of the large bowel was removed from a 34-year-old man with a familial disease that affects his gastrointestinal tract. The surgical specimen is shown in the image. This patient most likely carries a germline mutation in which of the following genes?

A 55-year-old male presents with longstanding gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) refractory to proton pump inhibitors. Upper endoscopy reveals a change in the distal esophageal mucosa characterized by salmon-colored, velvety epithelium extending several centimeters above the gastroesophageal junction. Biopsy of this tissue shows intestinal metaplasia with goblet cells. Which of the following complications is this patient at increased risk for?

A 42-year-old man presents with long-standing abdominal pain after meals, which is relieved by over-the-counter antacids. The patient has lost 10 kg in the past year. Physical examination reveals peripheral edema and ascites. Laboratory studies show decreased serum albumin but normal serum levels of transaminases and gastrin. Gross and microscopic examination of this patient’s stomach would most likely show which of the following pathologic changes?

A 35-year-old male presents to the gastroenterology clinic with a family history of colorectal cancer. His father was diagnosed with colorectal cancer at age 40, and his grandfather died of colorectal cancer at age 50. The patient is asymptomatic and has no significant medical history. On physical examination, there are no abnormal findings. Screening colonoscopy reveals the presence of numerous polyps throughout the colon, including the rectum. Biopsy of these polyps shows adenomatous changes. What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 32-year-old traveler returning from a recent trip to a developing country presents with high fever, abdominal pain, and diarrhea. Physical examination reveals hepatosplenomegaly and abdominal tenderness. Gastrointestinal endoscopy reveals multiple discrete longitudinal ulcers with a raised, erythematous base in the distal ileum and colon. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 60-year-old man presents with a 5-week history of difficulty swallowing. Physical examination is unremarkable. Upper endoscopy shows a large mass in the upper third of the esophagus. A biopsy is shown in the image. Which of the following is the most important risk factor for development of the condition in the patient?

A 28-year-old female presents with chronic diarrhea, weight loss, and bloating. She reports that her symptoms worsen after consuming foods containing wheat, barley, or rye. A small bowel biopsy is performed, and histological examination reveals villous atrophy, increased intraepithelial lymphocytes, and crypt hyperplasia in the duodenal mucosa. Which of the following histological findings is most characteristic of celiac sprue?

A 53-year-old woman complains of acute diarrhea and severe abdominal pain. She was recently treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics for community-acquired pneumonia. A CBC shows a WBC count of 24,000/μL. The patient subsequently develops septic shock and dies. A portion of her colon is shown at autopsy. These findings are typical of which of the following gastrointestinal diseases?

A 60-year-old man presents with epigastric pain after meals, with some nausea and vomiting. A burning sensation in the midepigastrium is relieved by antacids and H2 antagonists. Upper endoscopy demonstrates paired ulcers on both walls of the proximal duodenum. Which of the following represents the most common complication of this patient’s duodenal disease?

A patient with intestinal malabsorption is found to markedly improve when flour products (bread, noodles, etc.) are removed from his diet. At the height of the patient’s disease, marked histologic changes would be seen at which of the following sites?
A 17-year-old presented with intussusceptions and was found to be having a polyp. A biopsy is taken and is shown alongside. What is the likely diagnosis in this individual?

A 45-year-old woman presents with sudden attacks of wheezing, shortness of breath, and episodic hot fl ashes. She also reports abdominal cramps and diarrhea. Physical examination shows facial redness, pitting edema of the lower legs, and a murmur of tricuspid regurgitation. A 24-hour urine specimen contains elevated levels of 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid (5-HIAA). A CT scan of the abdomen demonstrates multiple 1 to 2-cm nodules in distal ileum. A small bowel resection is performed (shown in the image). The arrows point to submucosal tumors. Microscopic examination shows nests of cells with round and uniform nuclei. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
